title: How to Make a Gold Leaf Vase

steps.headline: Clean the vase.
steps.description: Wash the vase with warm water and soap. Pat it dry with a soft, clean towel, then wipe it down with rubbing alcohol. This will get rid of any oils that might prevent the foil from sticking.

steps.headline: Mask off you vase with painter's tape, if desired.
steps.description: If you want nice, crisp lines, apply some painter's tape just above where you want the gold leaf to end. If you want a jagged line instead, you can skip this step.

steps.headline: Cut the gold leaf down to smaller pieces, if desired.
steps.description: You don't absolutely have to do this, but many people find it easier to apply the gold leaf in smaller pieces. Whole sheets are typically harder to remove.

steps.headline: Apply gold leaf adhesive to your vase.
steps.description: Avoid getting any onto the painter's tape. You can use the brush-on kind or the spray-on kind. The brush on kind is great if you want a jagged line. The spray-on kind is great if you need to cove a large area. For small or delicate areas, use a gold leaf adhesive pen instead. Most types of gold leaf will have a paper backing. Leave this backing on the gold leaf.

steps.headline: Let the adhesive dry.
steps.description: Once the glue dries, it will be tacky and ready for the gold leaf. Read the label on your gold leaf adhesive as each brand will be a little different.

steps.headline: Press the gold leaf onto the adhesive.
steps.description: If your gold leaf has a paper backing, make sure that you place it gold-side-down onto the vase. If your gold leaf does not have a paper backing, it would be a good idea to handle it with tweezers so that it does not stick against your skin.

steps.headline: Gently rub the back of the gold leaf against the vase.
steps.description: If your gold leaf has a paper backing, gently rub your finger against it. If your gold leaf does not have a paper backing, gently brush the gold leaf with a soft, watercolor brush.

steps.headline: Peel the paper backing away.
steps.description: Some of the gold leaf may be sticking up. If this happens, simply smooth it down with a soft, clean brush. If your gold leaf did not have a paper backing, you can skip this step.

steps.headline: Continue applying gold leaf.
steps.description: If the adhesive starts to lose its tack, you may have to apply more on. Keep applying the gold leaf, rubbing it, then peeling the paper backing away until your design is finished.

steps.headline: Brush off the excess gold leaf with a paintbrush.
steps.description: Use a soft, clean brush, such as a watercolor brush, to gently brush away any excess gold leaf.

steps.headline: Peel away any stencils and painter's tape.
steps.description: Be very careful while doing this. If you get any chips in your work, you can try filling them in with extra gold leaf. The gold leaf will only stick to the areas that have adhesive on them.

steps.headline: Use a paintbrush to apply gold leaf sealer over the gold leaf.
steps.description: Extend the sealer just past the edges of the gold leaf onto the vase. This will help seal the gold leaf in further and prevent it from sticking. Don't worry if the sealer goes on milky; it will turn clear.

steps.headline: Let the sealer dry completely.
steps.description: As the sealer dries, it will turn clear. How long this takes depends on the type of sealer you used. Some only take 15 to 20 minutes to dry while others need a few hours.

steps.headline: Clean the vase.
steps.description: Wash the vase with soap and water, then pat it dry with a soft, clean towel. Wipe the entire vase down using rubbing alcohol. This will get rid of any oils that might prevent the paint from sticking.

steps.headline: Mask off the areas you don't want painted with painter's tape.
steps.description: You do not have to cover the entire vase with painter's tape. Instead, wrap some painter's tape around your vase, just above where you want the gold to end. You will paint everything below that line.

steps.headline: Seal the tape in.
steps.description: Run a credit card over the tape. This ensures that the edges are firmly sealed against the glass. It will help prevent the paint from seeping under it.

steps.headline: Start applying gold paint to the vase with a foam sponge.
steps.description: Shake the paint bottle well, the pour a small amount onto a plate. Use a foam brush to pick up the paint, then dab on a thin layer onto the glass. Don't worry if it looks sheer. Apply the paint going in the same direction, ie: up-and-down. If you can't find any gold leaf paint, try gold enamel paint instead. It will give you a similar look.

steps.headline: Let the paint dry two hours before applying another coat.
steps.description: It's very important that you wait, or the paint may not cure properly. Once the two hours are up, apply another light coat of paint. Apply the paint going in the opposite direction, ie: left-and-right. If the paint still looks sheer after this, let the paint dry another two hours, then add a third coat.

steps.headline: Let the paint dry completely.
steps.description: How long it takes for the paint to dry depends on the type of paint you are using. In most cases, it will take about 24 hours. Refer to your bottle of paint for specific drying times. You can peel the tape away after 2 to 3 hours.

steps.headline: Carefully remove the tape.
steps.description: If you have not yet done so, carefully peel the tape away. Your lines should be crisp and neat. If there are any chips, fill them in using a thin brush and gold leaf paint. You can also use a gold leaf pen instead.
